conclusion: Analyze motion of objects A and B using v-t graphs to determine if accelerations are first increasing then decreasing over interval 0 to t1.
Graph shows velocity on y-axis and time on x-axis for objects A and B; time interval of interest is from t=0 to t=t1.
Object A's graph is a downward-opening parabola with velocity starting at 0, increasing to a maximum, then decreasing back to 0 at t1.
Object B's graph is similar to A's but positioned below A's.
Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with respect to time; mathematically, a = dv/dt.
On a v-t graph, acceleration is the slope of the graph at any point.
Question asks if acceleration of both objects is first increasing then decreasing during interval [0, t1].
Both graphs are parabolas that open downward.
For object A: At t=0, velocity v=0; velocity increases, reaches maximum between t=0 and t=t1, then decreases back to v=0 at t=t1.
Object B follows similar pattern but with lower peak velocity compared to A.
Maximum velocity occurs at midpoint of interval, i.e., at t=t1/2 due to symmetry of parabolas.
Acceleration is the slope of the v-t graph; need to examine how slope changes over interval [0, t1].
For downward-opening parabola v=k(t-t1/2)^2+c: From t=0 to t=t1/2, slope starts positive and decreases as curve flattens at peak.
At t=t1/2, slope is 0 since tangent is horizontal at maximum.
From t=t1/2 to t=t1, slope becomes negative and continues to decrease (more negative) as curve steepens downward.
Need rate of change of acceleration (jerk), i.e., derivative of acceleration with respect to time.
For parabola v=-kt^2+mt+c: First derivative dv/dt=a=-2kt+m; Second derivative d^2v/dt^2=da/dt=-2k.
k>0 for downward-opening parabola, so da/dt=-2k is negative constant; acceleration decreasing linearly over interval [0, t1].
At t=0, a=m (positive); at t=t1/2, a=0; at t=t1, a=-m (negative).
